trial_identification.studytitle: A pharmacokinetic trial of Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) naltrexone implants in a small cohort of illicit opioid dependent persons
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A pharmacokinetic trial of Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) naltrexone implants in a small cohort of illicit opioid dependent persons

conditions.healthcondition: Pharmacokinetic properties of a sustained release naltrexone implant in illicit opioid dependent persons

interventions.interventions: This is a phase 1 pharmacokinetic trial of the naltrexone implant. Subjects will be recruited from patients presenting for treatment for illicit opioid dependence as defined by DSM-1V criteria. Following collection of baseline data, blood and urine, the patient will be treated with a naltrexone implant as per standard clinic procedures. An intravenous cannula will be inserted at the time of implant administration for the collection of pharmacokinetic bloods at 2, 6, 12, 18, 22, 26, 30, 48 and 72 hours post-procedure. Patients will be requested to collect a 24 hoour urine sample beginning 24 hours after implant adminsitration. Following this initial intensive sampling schedule and removal of the cannula line, patients will continue to have blood collected at weekly, then fortnightly intervals during routine clinical follow up until 6 months post-procedure. Regular urine samples will be collected for urine drug screens. Self-reported health data will be collected during the 6 month observation period and the site of implant will be assessed for infection or allergic responses.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Blood levels of naltrexone and 6-beta-naltrexol over 72 hours.
Renal clearance by measuring the urinary concentration of naltrexone and 6-beta-naltrexol from all urine passed between 24 and 48 hours.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 1) Plasma concentration of naltrexone and 6-beta-naltrexol from 72 hours to 6 months determined from blood samples collected.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Post-procedure: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6 and 8 weeks, then monthly to 6 months.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 2) Renal clearance by measuring the urinary concentration of naltrexone and 6-beta-naltrexol from 72 hours to 6 months.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Determined by 24 hour urine samples, and other samples collected at 1,3 and 6 months.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 3) Other health outcome measures including evaluation of wound/implant site.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Opioid dependence: no prior GMP naltrexone implants, informed consent
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: No other naltrexone implants in the past 2 years

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: School of Psychiatry and Clinical Neurosciences, University of Western Australia

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of the study is the in vivo investigation of the plasma concentration and the renal excretion rates following Naltrexone implantation. This will allow us to determine the pharmacokinetic properties of the implants. In other words, the study assesses how quickly naltrexone is released following an implant and how quickly it is processed by the body. Blood and urine samples will be collected frequently over the 1st 72 hour and then at extended intervals to 6 months.
